Posts.Content: I'm sick of being listless, tired, forgetful, taking meds to counter act meds and basically feeling like I'm already dead. My stats are in my signature so I don't want to retype it. Has anyone else had experience in stopping HT and would you share the results? I'm due for my next injection in January and intend to see what the PSA is and then make my decision.
Posts.Signature: Age 47, 12/1/11 - Diagnosed with Prostate cancer. PSA- 28, Gleason 4+3=7, Biopsy 7 of 12 samples positive. 1/31/12 Radical Prostectomy via DaVinci robot at Henry Ford Macomb. Surgeon, Dr. Randy Chudler. I would recommend him. Final pathology, 1mm cancer remained. March 2012 PSA- .07 June 2012 PSA- 0.0 December of 2012 after no return of erection I received a penile implant (BAD Decision). Jan. 2013 PSA .17 April 2013 PSA .25 May 2013 began Eligard 60 Hormone Therapy May 2013 8 weeks of External Radiation. September 2013 PSA .04 continued Eligard Jan 2014 PSA 0.0 continued Eligard March 2016 PSA <0.1 Oct 2016 PSA <0.1 Jan 2017 PSA <0.1 Oct 2017 PSA <0.1 June 2018 PSA 0.2

Posts.Title: Thinking about quitting HT. Has anyone else?

Posts.Content: I appreciate the feedback. I have until January before the next shot. I can't do anything but fantasize about being able to return to playing music in a band, date my wife instead of ending my evening by 8:00pm and generally assuming I'll feel better without the hormones and the rest of crap I have to take to counteract the treatment anyway. I guess this is a better place to rant and explore my eventual demise than Facebook so for that I am truly grateful. If I become too much of a downer for this site, let me know. Cheers!

Posts.Content: Yes indeed, Merry Christmas to all. Enjoy another Christmas with your families and friends and take the time to appreciate it. I'm reminded of the words of Warren Zevon (Werewolves of London fame) during an interview with David Letterman after finding out he had cancer. David asked if he has any new perspective on life since finding out. Warren's reply was "Enjoy every sandwich".

Posts.Title: Finally some good news!

Posts.Content: Hi everybody, I don't know why it took me so long to look for this forum. I'm a member of others and it never dawned on me until today that this may exist. I'm 49. I found out I had cancer 2 years ago. PSA 28, Gleason Score 4+3=7 Jan of 2012 I had my prostate removed via robotic surgery. By July of 12 PSA was 0.0. Dec of 2012 I had a penile implant and during the one month follow up doc visit they did a blood draw. I went back for a PSA check in April of 2013. It was .25, January's was .17. I began HT in May and then 8 weeks of External Radition. In Sept my PSA was .04. That's my tale. I look forward to reading of the experiences of the others on the forum. Thank you!
Posts.Title: Greetings from (near) Detroit

Posts.Content: I was told that they could see a very small point of cancer cells on good tissue (I assume nerves) that they didn't want to disturb because it was so small. After pathology results there was a 1mm piece left behind. I guess that means positive margins. I was told that the cancer left was so small that the body could kill it without issue. I thought I was home free when I hit 0.0. Now I have a different outlook.

Posts.Title: Greetings from (near) Detroit

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lLance Could you please tell me if you are pleased with your choice. At 66 going on 67 in Mar. I want to have one, but question whether it is worth going through another surgery at this point in my life. Hi Lance, I'll give you the straight poop on what I feel about my implant. Of everything I have done in my life, it is my only true regret. I take full responsibility for it. My doctor didn't talk me into it. I didn't wait very long to get the implant after the prostate surgery. The kick off of the whole prostate thing came from watching TV commercials about Low T. Things weren't working like they used to so I went to the Doc and after a DRE, my life changed forever. flkjr - yes it was nerve sparing surgery. I tried ciallas and did injections. The pills did nothing, the injections were impressive but painful, very painful. I had delusions of grandeur thinking I could pump it up and go as long as my wife wanted. I moved forward with the implant and it was far worse that the prostate surgery for pain and recovery. There was something psychological about it was well, seeing it looking like a hot dog over cooked in the microwave and bruising that looked like I was kicked by a Clydesdale. Once I healed, about the same time as the prostate surgery, and I got the green light from the doc to have sex, I pumped it up. Disappointment is the only word to describe it. I was about 8". According to my wife, I had something to be proud of. Now it's about 5" and slimmer. When I asked the doctor, he said he used the largest implant that they make and it didn't fill the tissue like the blood used to. The few times we tried to have sex before the PSA started to rise and I went on HT it was nearly as painful as the injections. The head is now soft because there is no blood to inflate it. With the filled saline tubes behind the head pushing against my wife, it feels like pinching the webbing between your thumb and your hand as hard as you can. (Not 100% accurate but the only way I can describe it). When I was able to achieve penetration it wasn't much more than the now soft and pliable head. I hoped for her to finish quickly so that the pain would subside. I heard from a friend who also got an implant around the same time that he had similar experiences. He recommended using a fake vagina to desensitize it. That didn't help much. I actually found starting HT a relief because now I didn't have any desire, my wife knew that it was chemical castration and there was no longer any reason to try and make the implant worthwhile. I have heard that others have had fine experiences (by the paid spokesmen at the discussion group hosted by the doctors office) but this is my tale. Just living with it and knowing that I eliminated ANY chance of having things recur naturally is a constant reminder of the worst choice of my life.

Posts.Content: Hi Bravehardon, luckily I do have insurance that covers the injections, sort of. I have a $4k deductible which for the past 2 years I have been able to meet by about April. I didn't have any adverse effects from the radiation but I think that it did contribute to the fatigue and was compounded by the HT.

Posts.Title: Is it back again?

Posts.Content: Thanks Jim. It was the doctor that showed me the results. It was 0.05. He explained the test is acurate down to 0.02. I know I'm reacting early. I really don't care anymore but it's driving my family nuts.
Posts.Title: Is it back again?

Posts.Content: I had a radical prostectomy in 2012. It was stage 3. It 2013 I had radiation and hormone treatments. 18 months later, psa was 0.0. 6 months later, psa is at 0.05. Being that it's come back before, I think I'm back there again. Any similar experiences? Thank you
